PHYSICS.chapter_title: Physics Form Two - FTNA 2020 Sample Examination
PHYSICS.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM TWO NATIONAL ASSESSMENT
031 PHYSICS
(For both School and Private Candidates)
Time: 2:30 Hours

Instructions:
1. This paper consists of sections A, B and C with a total of ten (10) questions.
2. Answer all questions in the spaces provided.
3. Section A carries thirty (30) marks, section B fifty (50) marks and section C carries twenty (20) marks.
4. All answers must be written in the spaces provided.
5. All writing must be in blue or black ink except diagrams which must be in pencil.
6. Calculators and cellular phones are not allowed in the examination room.
7. Write your Assessment Number at the top right corner of every page.
8. Where necessary the following constants may be used:
   Acceleration due to gravity, g = 10 m/s²
   Density of water = 1 g/cm³ or 1000 kg/m³

SECTION A (30 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

1. For each of the items (i) - (x), choose the correct answer from among the given alternatives and write its letter beside the item number.

   (i) The SI unit of force is
 - A. Joule
 - B. Newton
 - C. Watt
 - D. Pascal

   (ii) The property of matter which makes it resist any change in its state of rest or uniform motion is called
 - A. momentum
 - B. inertia
 - C. energy
 - D. power

   (iii) The image formed by a plane mirror is
 - A. real and inverted
 - B. virtual and erect
 - C. real and erect
 - D. virtual and inverted

   (iv) The process by which a liquid changes into gas without heating is called
 - A. evaporation
 - B. boiling
 - C. condensation
 - D. sublimation

   (v) The instrument used to measure electric current is
 - A. ammeter
 - B. voltmeter
 - C. ohmmeter
 - D. galvanometer

   (vi) The S.I unit of pressure is
 - A. Pascal
 - B. Newton
 - C. Joule
 - D. Watt

   (vii) A body of mass 5 kg is moving with a velocity of 4 m/s. Its momentum is
 - A. 20 kg m/s
 - B. 9 kg m/s
 - C. 1.25 kg m/s
 - D. 0.8 kg m/s

   (viii) The focal length of a concave mirror is
 - A. positive
 - B. negative
 - C. zero
 - D. infinite

   (ix) The device which converts mechanical energy into electrical energy is
 - A. dynamo
 - B. motor
 - C. transformer
 - D. generator

   (x) The quantity which remains constant in simple harmonic motion is
 - A. velocity
 - B. acceleration
 - C. frequency
 - D. amplitude

2. Match the items in List A with the responses in List B by writing the letter of the correct response beside the item number in the table provided.

   List A

   (i) Hooke's law

   (ii) Archimedes' principle

   (iii) Pascal's principle

   (iv) Bernoulli's principle

   (v) Newton's third law

   List B

   A. Pressure in a fluid is transmitted equally in all directions

   B. Every action has an equal and opposite reaction

   C. The upward buoyant force equals the weight of the fluid displaced

   D. Stress is directly proportional to strain

   E. Pressure decreases as speed increases in a fluid

3. (a) Define the term 'pressure'.

   (b) Calculate the pressure exerted by a force of 200 N on an area of 0.5 m².

4. (a) State the law of conservation of energy.

   (b) A car of mass 1000 kg is moving at 20 m/s. Calculate its kinetic energy.

5. (a) What is meant by 'specific heat capacity'?

   (b) How much heat is required to raise the temperature of 2 kg of water from 20°C to 100°C? (Specific heat capacity of water = 4200 J/kg°C)

6. (a) Draw a diagram of a simple pendulum.

   (b) State the factors affecting the period of a simple pendulum.

SECTION B (50 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

7. (a) Explain why a steel ship floats on water while a steel needle sinks.

   (b) A stone of mass 2 kg is dropped from a height of 45 m. Calculate its velocity just before hitting the ground. (g = 10 m/s²)

8. (a) Define 'power' and state its SI unit.

   (b) A machine lifts a load of 500 N through a height of 10 m in 20 s. Calculate the power developed.

9. (a) What is meant by 'electromagnetic induction'?

   (b) Describe how an electric bell works.

10. (a) Explain the formation of rainbow.

    (b) Draw a ray diagram showing the path of light through a convex lens.

SECTION C (20 Marks)
Answer question 11.

11. (a) Describe an experiment to determine the focal length of a concave mirror.

    (b) A concave mirror has a focal length of 20 cm. Calculate the position of the image when an object is placed 30 cm from the mirror.
    (c) State three uses of concave mirrors.

PAnswers.chapter_title: Physics Form Two - FTNA 2020 Sample Examination Answers
PAnswers.content:
1. (i) B (ii) B (iii) B (iv) A (v) A (vi) A (vii) A (viii) A (ix) A (x) D

2. (i) D (ii) C (iii) A (iv) E (v) B

3. (a) Pressure is force per unit area.

 (b) P = F/A = 200 / 0.5 = 400 Pa

4. (a) Energy can neither be created nor destroyed but can be changed from one form to another.

 (b) KE = (1/2)mv² = (1/2)×1000×(20)² = 200,000 J

5. (a) Specific heat capacity is the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of 1 kg of a substance by 1°C.

 (b) Q = mcΔT = 2 × 4200 × 80 = 672,000 J

6. (a) [Diagram of simple pendulum: bob, string, pivot]

 (b) Length of pendulum, acceleration due to gravity.

7. (a) The ship displaces a volume of water whose weight is greater than its own weight due to its shape (Archimedes' principle). The needle displaces less water than its weight.

 (b) v² = u² + 2gs = 0 + 2×10×45 = 900 → v = 30 m/s

8. (a) Power is the rate of doing work. Unit: Watt.

 (b) Work = Fd = 500×10 = 5000 J. Power = work/time = 5000/20 = 250 W

9. (a) Production of electricity by changing magnetic field.

 (b) [Explanation: current through coil creates electromagnet, attracts armature, breaks circuit, spring returns, repeats]

10. (a) Dispersion and refraction of sunlight in water droplets.

 (b) [Ray diagram: object, convex lens, principal axis, rays converging to image]

11. (a) [Method: object at C, screen until sharp image, measure distances]

 (b) 1/f = 1/u + 1/v → 1/20 = 1/30 + 1/v → v = 60 cm (real image) (c) Shaving mirror, dentist mirror, reflecting telescope.

Note: This is a sample based on typical FTNA 2020 Physics format and questions from reliable sources. Actual paper may vary slightly in wording but covers similar topics.

BIOLOGY.chapter_title: Biology Form Two - FTNA 2025 Sample Examination
BIOLOGY.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM TWO NATIONAL ASSESSMENT
033 BIOLOGY
(For both School and Private Candidates)
Time: 2:00 Hours

Instructions:
1. This paper consists of sections A, B and C with a total of ten (10) questions.
2. Answer all questions in the spaces provided.
3. Section A carries fifteen (15) marks, section B seventy (70) marks and section C carries fifteen (15) marks.
4. All answers must be written in the spaces provided.
5. All writing must be in blue or black ink except diagrams which must be in pencil.
6. Calculators, cellular phones and any unauthorised materials are not allowed in the assessment room.
7. Write your Assessment Number at the top right corner of every page.

SECTION A (15 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

1. For each of the items (i) - (x), choose the correct answer from among the given alternatives and write its letter beside the item number.

   (i) The branch of science which deals with the study of living things is called
 - A. Chemistry
 - B. Physics
 - C. Biology
 - D. Geology

   (ii) The ability of living organisms to detect and respond to changes in the environment is known as
 - A. reproduction
 - B. irritability
 - C. growth
 - D. respiration

   (iii) Which of the following is not a characteristic of living things?
 - A. Movement
 - B. Nutrition
 - C. Photosynthesis
 - D. Excretion

   (iv) The basic unit of life is
 - A. tissue
 - B. organ
 - C. cell
 - D. system

   (v) The process by which green plants make their own food using sunlight is called
 - A. respiration
 - B. transpiration
 - C. photosynthesis
 - D. fermentation

   (vi) The kingdom that includes bacteria is
 - A. Fungi
 - B. Plantae
 - C. Monera
 - D. Protoctista

   (vii) The organ responsible for gaseous exchange in humans is
 - A. heart
 - B. lungs
 - C. kidney
 - D. liver

   (viii) HIV is transmitted mainly through
 - A. sharing food
 - B. unprotected sexual intercourse
 - C. mosquito bites
 - D. shaking hands

   (ix) The movement of water molecules from a region of high concentration to low concentration through a semi-permeable membrane is
 - A. diffusion
 - B. osmosis
 - C. active transport
 - D. transpiration

   (x) The balance of nature refers to
 - A. food chains and webs
 - B. ecological interactions
 - C. biodiversity maintenance
 - D. all of the above

2. Match the items in List A with the responses in List B by writing the letter of the correct response beside the item number in the table provided.

   List A

   (i) Chloroplast

   (ii) Nucleus

   (iii) Vacuole

   (iv) Cell wall

   (v) Mitochondrion

   List B

   A. Controls cell activities

   B. Site of photosynthesis

   C. Site of respiration

   D. Stores cell sap

   E. Provides support in plant cells

SECTION B (70 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

3. (a) Define the term 'biology'.

   (b) List five branches of biology and explain one.

4. (a) What is first aid?

   (b) Describe how to provide first aid for a snake bite.

5. (a) Explain the importance of immunization.

   (b) Name three diseases that can be prevented by immunization.

6. (a) Draw and label the structure of an animal cell.

   (b) State the differences between plant and animal cells.

7. (a) Define classification.

   (b) Name the five kingdoms of living things and give an example for each.

8. (a) What is nutrition?

   (b) Explain the difference between autotrophic and heterotrophic nutrition.

9. (a) Define gaseous exchange.

   (b) Describe the process of respiration in humans.

SECTION C (15 Marks)
Answer question 10.

10. Discuss the importance of transport in living things. Give examples from plants and animals.

BAnswers.chapter_title: Biology Form Two - FTNA 2025 Sample Examination Answers
BAnswers.content:
1. (i) C - Biology is the scientific study of living organisms and their interactions with the environment. This helps students understand the scope of the subject.

 (ii) B - Irritability, also known as sensitivity, allows organisms to respond to stimuli like light or touch, which is essential for survival, such as plants growing towards sunlight.

 (iii) C - Photosynthesis is a process specific to some organisms like plants, not a universal characteristic. Characteristics of living things include MR GRENS: Movement, Respiration, Growth, Reproduction, Excretion, Nutrition, Sensitivity.

 (iv) C - The cell is the smallest unit that can perform all life processes independently. Understanding this is fundamental to biology.

 (v) C - Photosynthesis uses carbon dioxide, water, and sunlight to produce glucose and oxygen. The equation is 6CO₂ + 6H₂O → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ (in presence of chlorophyll and light).

 (vi) C - Monera includes prokaryotic organisms like bacteria, which lack a nucleus.

 (vii) B - Lungs facilitate the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide during breathing.

 (viii) B - HIV spreads through bodily fluids like blood, semen, etc., mainly via unprotected sex, sharing needles, or mother-to-child. Prevention includes using condoms and avoiding sharing sharp objects.

 (ix) B - Osmosis is crucial for water absorption in roots and maintaining cell turgor.

 (x) D - Balance of nature involves ecosystems maintaining stability through food chains, webs, and interactions like predation and symbiosis.

2. (i) B - Chloroplast contains chlorophyll for capturing light energy in photosynthesis.

 (ii) A - Nucleus houses DNA and directs protein synthesis and cell division.

 (iii) D - Vacuole in plants stores water, nutrients, and waste, helping in turgidity.

 (iv) E - Cell wall, made of cellulose in plants, provides rigidity and protection.

 (v) C - Mitochondrion is the powerhouse, where ATP is produced via cellular respiration.

3. (a) Biology is the study of living organisms, their structure, function, growth, origin, evolution, and distribution.

 (b) Branches: Botany (study of plants), Zoology (study of animals), Microbiology (study of microorganisms), Ecology (study of interactions between organisms and environment), Genetics (study of heredity). For example, Ecology helps understand how pollution affects wildlife, aiding conservation efforts.

4. (a) First aid is immediate care given to an injured or ill person before professional medical help arrives, to prevent worsening or save life.

 (b) For snake bite: Keep calm, immobilize the limb, apply pressure bandage if not venomous, seek medical help immediately. Do not cut or suck the wound, as it can spread venom.

5. (a) Immunization introduces weakened pathogens to stimulate antibody production, providing immunity against diseases without causing illness.

 (b) Polio, Measles, Tuberculosis (TB). Vaccines like OPV for polio prevent paralysis.

6. (a) [Diagram: Animal cell with labels - cell membrane, cytoplasm, nucleus, mitochondria, ribosomes, etc.]

 (b) Plant cells have cell wall, chloroplasts, large central vacuole; animal cells have centrioles, smaller vacuoles, no chloroplasts. These differences relate to their functions: plants photosynthesize, animals move more.

7. (a) Classification is grouping organisms based on shared characteristics for easy study and identification.

 (b) Monera (e.g., Bacteria), Protoctista (e.g., Amoeba), Fungi (e.g., Mushroom), Plantae (e.g., Maize), Animalia (e.g., Human). This system, by Linnaeus, uses binomial nomenclature like Homo sapiens.

8. (a) Nutrition is the process of obtaining and using food for growth, repair, and energy.

 (b) Autotrophic: Organisms make own food (e.g., plants via photosynthesis). Heterotrophic: Depend on others (e.g., animals eating plants/animals). This distinction shows energy flow in ecosystems.

9. (a) Gaseous exchange is the diffusion of gases (O₂ in, CO₂ out) across a moist surface.

 (b) In humans, air enters via nose/mouth, to trachea, bronchi, alveoli where O₂ diffuses into blood, CO₂ out. Respiration: Inhalation (diaphragm contracts, volume increases), exhalation (relaxes, volume decreases). This maintains oxygen for cellular respiration: glucose + O₂ → CO₂ + H₂O + energy.

10. Transport moves substances like water, nutrients, gases, wastes within organisms. In plants: Xylem transports water/minerals from roots (via osmosis/transpiration pull), phloem transports food from leaves. Importance: Distributes nutrients for growth, removes wastes. In animals: Blood carries O₂ from lungs, nutrients from intestines, hormones; removes CO₂ to lungs, urea to kidneys. Importance: Supplies cells with essentials, maintains homeostasis. Without transport, multicellular organisms couldn't function as cells far from sources would die.

Note: This is a sample based on the official NECTA FTNA Biology format from 2022 (latest available, no changes noted for 2025). Actual paper may vary slightly in wording but covers similar topics.
